snippet: Witnesses said the refinery in Baiji had fallen to attackers from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, but some Iraqi officials asserted that fighting was still going on in the facility.
abstract: Refinery workers, witnesses and an Iraqi Army officer report the seizure of Iraq’s biggest oil refinery by Sunni extremists after army helicopter gunships fail to repel their attack; other Iraqi officials, including the commander of the garrison defending the refinery in Baiji, assert that fighting is still going on inside the extensive facility, shut down by the violence.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and SUADAD AL-SALHY
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Tikrit, Iraq, Rick Gladstone from New York and Michael D. Shear from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Witnesses said the refinery in Baiji had fallen to attackers from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, but some Iraqi officials asserted that fighting was still going on in the facility.

headline.main: Extremists Attack Iraq’s Biggest Oil Refinery
headline.print_headline: Sunni Extremists Are Said to Take Control of Iraq’s Biggest Oil Refinery

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
